titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Holmes family papers 1977.632
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-18 21:23:46 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection contains the Holmes family's legal papers relating to deaths and estates from 1798-1851. The Holmes family lived in various counties in upstate New York.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The papers were formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: The Holmes family lived in various counties in upstate New York, including Westchester, Albany, Cayuga, and Saratoga counties.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Holmes family papers, 1977.632, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the Holmes family's legal papers, including: papers concerning the estate of Daniel Holmes; an affidavit concerning the death of John Holmes; a notification of settlement for the estate of Lothrop Holmes; petitions from Burroughs and Rosekrans Holmes concerning the estate of their father, Thomas; and the last will and testament of Edward Holmes.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
